title: Can a police officer modify a police report? - Quora

response.answer_text: Officers generally don't have access to modify reports once they are put into the database software system the department uses to keep track of reports. I really think this is mostly because the database would be a screwed-up mess if you let officers muck around in it. In addition to that, once a report is approved by the boss, various hardcopies generally get made and sent around to all the different places where they're filed: records division, prosecutor's office, etc. This is terribly inefficient in terms of how modern office systems are supposed to work, and it kills a lot of trees, but in the legal world everybody wants their own hard copy. So, we end up with hard copies all over the place, and if an officer wanted to alter a report after it's been approved he would have to chase down all those hard copies and replace them. Of course, an officer can always file a supplemental report to be added to the case file to add any new information or even correct mistakes in the original, but the original will still be there.

In a limited fashion, yes. Policy in my department is that an officer may modify a police report any time before final review by the Records department. To explain, when an officer writes a report, it is reviewed by a supervisor, who then either approves it or sends it back to the officer for clarification or corrections. After the supervisor approves the report, it is given to Records for a final review. After that review, the report is locked and no more edits are allowed by the system. If an officer needs to make a correction or clarification after supervisor approval but prior to Records approval, the officer is required to notify a supervisor about the correction. If something needs clarification later, then a supplemental narrative is opened and the clarification is made in the supplement, which then goes through the same approval process. Things may work differently in other departments.  (Edit) As clarification, our report system has full audit capabilities and you can see who edited what and when (the system requires unique logins).

Change the report or change some information in the report? The difference is important. Yes-clarifications can be made, however they should be clearly noted as such and not simply an erasure or deletion and then a rewrite. The clarification should also not be an alteration of the original report but written as a part of a supplemental so that both representations are still present. Acceptable would be wording along the lines of,” Subsequent investigation (with an explanation of exactly the nature of that investigation, i.e., interviews, evidence found, etc.) found that the earlier conclusion that xxxxx was found to not be accurate and xxxx is now believed to have occurred.” A complete rewrite of a report would be questionable

I am not aware of what type of police report you have in mind while asking this question and secondly what do you exactly mean by word Modify. If police officer wishes to change some report, he certainly cant remove the initially submitted report. He can submit an additional report in continuation to the initial report, by mentioning the circumstances under which initial report was submitted and what circumstances compelled him to reconsider the initial report and then submit the improved report. Stealthily removing initial report and replacing it with newer one is never advisable. In geometry we were taught that the straight line is shortest, same applies to policing and police work.

Not legally but some have tried. Once a police report is written/typed it must be signed by the officer under oath that it is true and correct to the best of their knowledge and it is a felony to lie on a police report. Officers can send additional evidence reports which usually come from investigators or outside professionals that will go into the file with the police report. I have personally had a cop charged and sent to jail for filing two different police reports with obvious contradictions in the report.

Yes. On our department, new information and information that needs to be corrected is written on a supplemental report under the same file number as the original report. The report typically starts out with something like, “The purpose of this report is to proved active/ additional information….” “The purpose of this report is to correct information in the original report….”

In regards to spelling and grammar, they get stabbed to death with a red felt pen all the time. Once approved and processed by the records unit. Not going to happen. Supplemental reports can be filed under the master control number seemingly forever. Every year, for example, some LAPD Detective has to fill out a follow-up report to the 1940's Black Dahlia murder, it reads, "No additional leads received - case continued". Please consider that one such supplemental report might just outline evidence EXONERATING an arrested suspect. You'd want that report filed, right?
Removing/replacing a report is illegal. Once it has been approved and filed, any changes or additional information must be submitted in supplemental reports.
Yes, officers can amend or supplement their reports as the information changes.
Yes I have see them do this. However it's usually when they are lying. Most of the time I confront the discrepancy to attack his credibility.
Yes, it's done all the time they have forms called “supplemental reports” the original report must not be altered but can be amended by a follow up report
It depends on whether that report has been uploaded and filed or if printed, disseminated. If a report needs to be revised then the correct way is to do a supplement to the original.
